message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the decreased sensation, suggest a neuropathy, which is commonly caused by a Vitamin B1 deficiency. Vitamin C deficiency usually causes scurvy, Vitamin B6 deficiency usually causes peripheral neuropathy and cheilosis, and Vitamin A deficiency usually causes night blindness and Bitot spots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest beriberi, which is caused by Vitamin B1 deficiency. Dilated cardiomyopathy and increased cardiac output are among the cardiovascular manifestations of Vitamin B1 deficiency, while decreased sensation over both extremities is a neurological manifestation. Vitamin C deficiency can cause scurvy, which presents with bleeding gums and joint pain. Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and seizures, but not dilated cardiomyopathy. Vitamin A deficiency can cause night blindness and dry eyes but not the symptoms presented in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest thiamine deficiency, which is commonly seen in alcoholics and malnourished individuals. Thiamine deficiency can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy and peripheral neuropathy. Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, but this condition does not typically cause cardiac or neurological symptoms seen in this patient. Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neuropathy, but it does not cause dilated cardiomyopathy. Vitamin A deficiency can cause night blindness and skin problems, but it is not related to the symptoms in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest beriberi, a disease caused by Vitamin B1 deficiency. Dilated cardiomyopathy and increased cardiac output are common in cardiac beriberi, and sensory neuropathy can cause decreased sensation over both extremities. Vitamin C deficiency can cause scurvy, Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neuropathy, and Vitamin A deficiency can cause night blindness and dry eyes, none of which match the patient’s symptoms.

Vitamin A deficiency can cause night blindness and skin changes, but not cardiovascular or neurological symptoms.

Vitamin A deficiency can cause vision problems and skin changes, but it is not associated with peripheral neuropathy or dilated cardiomyopathy.
